linkTarget.anchoringText: Â

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: IHS Data, Midland Basin of the Permian Basin in West Texas, Horizontal Well Count in the Spraberry Trend in 12/2011 and 10/2016 colored by Operator Spraberry Wells up to 12 / 2011, Spraberry Wells up to 10 / 2016

formatted-caption.caption-text: IHS Data, Midland Basin of the Permian Basin in West Texas, Horizontal Well Count in the Spraberry Trend in 12/2011 and 10/2016 colored by Operator Spraberry Wells up to 12 / 2011, Spraberry Wells up to 10 / 2016

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 2 shows a normal frac stage on the left that was pumped according to the design schedule, and shows on the right a stage that was pumped with an unplanned sweep as a result of observed challenges with the treating pressure response. When the latter occurred, attempts were made to reduce the volume of water needed for sweeping the wellbore that which would be of utmost importance in areas of water availability limitations which has become even a bigger strain with the recent increases in frac design and proppant volumes.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: (Left) Typical Job Design with no Unplanned Sweeps (Right) Job with One Unplanned Sweep

formatted-caption.caption-text: (Left) Typical Job Design with no Unplanned Sweeps (Right) Job with One Unplanned Sweep

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Typical Job Design with no Unplanned Sweeps

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 3 presents an example of a resulting near wellbore screenout. In this case, a dirty sweep which comprises of cutting the proppant in the slurry to minimal concentrations instead of a pumping a full wellbore of a clean sweep to aid in water consumption management, was pumped to reduce the encountered pressure challenges. However, it appears that the dirty sweep did not allow a full wellbore and perforation cleanout that which has ultimately caused the near wellbore screenout to occur potentially as a result of the perforation clusters locking up.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Near Wellbore Screen-out potentially caused by pumping a dirty sweep instead of a full wellbore volume clean sweep that has compromised the perforations and the proppant's ability to be pushed through

formatted-caption.caption-text: Near Wellbore Screen-out potentially caused by pumping a dirty sweep instead of a full wellbore volume clean sweep that has compromised the perforations and the proppant's ability to be pushed through

linkTarget.anchoringText: The distribution of unplanned sweeps is depicted in Figure 4. 60% of the stages were pumped without the need for unplanned sweeps while the remaining 40% were pumped with anywhere between 1 and 3 sweeps total depending on the number of times the stage encountered pressure challenges to avoid screenouts.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Pie chart showing the distribution of sweeps across the 8 horizontal wellbores under study

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pie chart showing the distribution of sweeps across the 8 horizontal wellbores under study

linkTarget.anchoringText: An in-house algorithm was developed using Gamma Ray logs measured while drilling, drilling rate of penetration and Young's modulus calculated from seismic to create a rock typing methodology along the wellbore of the study wells. Eleven distinct rock facies were determined and three well types were established. Figure 5 (up) below shows the rock facies distribution in the studied wellbores and Figure 5 (down) shows a cross plot of Young's Modulus and Gamma Ray highlighting clearly the three distinct well types.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: (up) Facies population across all 8 study wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: (up) Facies population across all 8 study wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: An in-house algorithm was developed using Gamma Ray logs measured while drilling, drilling rate of penetration and Young's modulus calculated from seismic to create a rock typing methodology along the wellbore of the study wells. Eleven distinct rock facies were determined and three well types were established. Figure 5 (up) below shows the rock facies distribution in the studied wellbores and Figure 5 (down) shows a cross plot of Young's Modulus and Gamma Ray highlighting clearly the three distinct well types.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: (down) Scatter plot depicting well types

formatted-caption.caption-text: (down) Scatter plot depicting well types

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures 6 through 8 show the input curves and rock types determined for each of the identified three well types on identical scales. Type 1 wells are dominated by facies 4-7. They have a higher Young's modulus and lower GR. These wells have the highest average drilling rate of penetration.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Type 1 Well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Type 1 Well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures 6 through 8 show the input curves and rock types determined for each of the identified three well types on identical scales. Type 1 wells are dominated by facies 4-7. They have a higher Young's modulus and lower GR. These wells have the highest average drilling rate of penetration.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Type 2 Well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures 6 through 8 show the input curves and rock types determined for each of the identified three well types on identical scales. Type 1 wells are dominated by facies 4-7. They have a higher Young's modulus and lower GR. These wells have the highest average drilling rate of penetration.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Type 3 Well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Type 3 Well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures 9 â 11 shows the observed distribution of unplanned sweeps in the three type wells. Type 1 wells account for majority of the observed sweeps with a 74% chance of a sweep occurring while pumping. Type 2 wells have a 15% probability of a sweep occurring while type 3 wells have a 20% chance of having a sweep. The different facies and treatment behaviors can be mostly attributed to their landing targets which determine the dominant lithology at the wellbore.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Type 1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Type 1

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12 above shows a graphical representation of equation 1 with discharge coefficient ranging from 0.7 to 0.9. The perforation friction and calculated area are shown at the different measuring points for a single stage. This shows that the main effect of the 100 mesh sand is to increase the discharge coefficient by eroding the perforations making the fluid entry and exit smoother.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Average flow area analysis for Type 1 wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Average flow area analysis for Type 1 wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: The above analysis was broken down according to well types described previously to understand expectations when fracturing varying wellbore profiles and further assist real time operational decisions taken. Figures 14 through 16 break down the observed flow area changes for all the studied wells grouped by well types.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Â

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Petrophysical analysis

formatted-caption.caption-text: Petrophysical analysis

linkTarget.anchoringText: Sonic velocities for both compressional and shear components were calibrated using triaxial core testing data conducted in-situ horizontal effective stress (Sh'-confining stress) of about 2,900 psi and closure pressure measurements from a diagnostic fracture injection test (see figure 18). The initial geomechanical model was built around a cored well. To reduce the uncertainty in anisotropic mechanical properties the model was extended to other wells in the area.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: G Function analysis for closure pressure

formatted-caption.caption-text: G Function analysis for closure pressure

linkTarget.anchoringText: Multiple iterations in pore pressure gradients were applied by calibrating the derived stresses to the mini-frac's gathered closure stress public data and by performing pressure history matching (PHM). Based on log signatures and Dean's producible history, pore pressure ramp from sub hydrostatic to over pressure is created from 10ft above Dean to Wolfcamp. Figure 19 shows the pore pressure ramp and calculated minimum horizontal stress.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Pore pressure ramp and minimum stress for three wells in study area

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pore pressure ramp and minimum stress for three wells in study area

linkTarget.anchoringText: Â

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Effective stress and Young's modulus calibration to core data

formatted-caption.caption-text: Effective stress and Young's modulus calibration to core data

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fracture parent well modeling is critical to understanding the changes required in operational activities (Cherian et al., 2015). A model was created with a fine grid numerical planar simulator using the petrophysics and geomechanics models described as inputs to match the fracture treatment reports obtained from the field. Figure 21 shows the completed pressure history match with the end of job instantaneous shut in pressure matched. Figure shows the fracture geometries simulated for each cluster.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Pressure History Match Treatment Plot

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure History Match Treatment Plot

linkTarget.anchoringText: Â

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Pressure History Match Fracture Geometries Transverse 1, Transverse 2, Transverse 3, Transverse 4

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure History Match Fracture Geometries Transverse 1, Transverse 2, Transverse 3, Transverse 4

linkTarget.anchoringText: The number of perforations and discharge coefficient were modified as described in figure 12 to match the observed surface net pressures. Ugueto et al. (2016) demonstrated this by using DAS and DTS measurements to determine the number of clusters open during a fracturing treatment to evaluate perforation cluster efficiency. For this study, it is assumed that the toe-ward perforation cluster plugs off first and subsequent pressure increases are because of the next most dominant fracture simulated. Figure 23 shows the treatment pressure history match and figure 24 shows the observed fracture geometries.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Pressure History Match Treatment Plot with sweeps

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure History Match Treatment Plot with sweeps

linkTarget.anchoringText: The number of perforations and discharge coefficient were modified as described in figure 12 to match the observed surface net pressures. Ugueto et al. (2016) demonstrated this by using DAS and DTS measurements to determine the number of clusters open during a fracturing treatment to evaluate perforation cluster efficiency. For this study, it is assumed that the toe-ward perforation cluster plugs off first and subsequent pressure increases are because of the next most dominant fracture simulated. Figure 23 shows the treatment pressure history match and figure 24 shows the observed fracture geometries.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Fracture geometries showing greater growth in inner clusters Transverse 1, Transverse 2, Transverse 3, Transverse 4

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fracture geometries showing greater growth in inner clusters Transverse 1, Transverse 2, Transverse 3, Transverse 4
